question.title: PackageManager.getInstallerPackageName() returning unexpected packages as installers
question.body:
I’m using PackageManager.getInstallerPackageName() in my Android app to detect the installer source.

It usually returns expected installer packages like com.android.vending or com.samsung.android.app.store.

However, in some cases it returns a package I don’t recognize, for example: com.rhmsoft.edit

I also checked the reference documentation, but it doesn’t explain under what conditions unusual package names might be returned.

How does Android determine the value returned by getInstallerPackageName()?

I need this information because my app checks for the latest version on startup and prompts users to update if they're running an outdated build. However, I’ve noticed that some users are still on very old versions, and the installer source reported by the system appears to come from com.rhmsoft.edit.

question_comments.body: I've also seen text editors like com.rhmsoft.edit occasionally become the 'default app' for some files that otherwise don't have an appropriate app to open. If the user has a custom ROM with no stores, that could explain why nothing else has the default file association

You expect the installer to be an app store app which is a misunderstanding. If you download an APK file from a web site using chrome and give chrome the permission to install apps then Chrome will be the "installer". So any app that downloads an APK from somewhere in the net can get an installer and will the be returned from getInstallerPackageName()

I would assume that getInstallerPackageName() returns whatever used the PackageInstaller API to install the app, at least on API Level 21+. Considering that com.rhmsoft.edit is a programmer's editor, perhaps it is the installer for people using that app to work with decompiled editions of your app, or something like that.

I'm not really sure and haven't tested this, so this is just a guess, but com.rhmsoft.edit might possibly end up as a source if someone manually installed an APK, not through a specific store. The lack of auto-updates with a manual install may explain the old versions
